content: skeins i used about 40 grams of the yarn rowan kidsilk haze would be an excellent substitution for this yarn  knitting needles 1 set us 8/5 0mm needles or size needed to obtain gauge you may find it easier to use circular needles due to the large number of stitches after the ends are joined  yarn needle  blocking pins or wires gauge 16 sts and 21 row= 4 /10cm in stockinette row gauge is not particularly important but is given as a guideline pattern instructions cast on 60 sts using a provisional cast on work in stockinette knit all sts on rs purl all sts on ws to 27 inches ending with a rs row bend the fabric into a u shape and knit the sts from the provisional cast-on be sure not to twist the fabric lay the rectangle flat on a table and just slide the end with the provisional cast-on out to the left then up to form the u tip you may want to cross the last stitch of the first half and the first stitch of the last half when you make the join to add a little strength continue working across all stitches in stockinette to approximately 56 or desired length and bind off with a stretchy bind-off i used the following method k1 * k1 slip the tip of the left-hand needle into the 2 sts on the right-hand needle and knit them together through the back loop repeat from * across block the wrap by folding it in half into a flat rectangle and block the folded fabric to approximately 15 x 28 after it s dry you may want to mist the crease at the center front and center back with a bit of water to get rid of the fold mark weave in ends same thing only different v1 0 page 3 of 5 copyright 2012 - cheryl schumer only different variations and tips sizing if you would like to modify the size you may find it helpful to drape a long wide scarf over your shoulders with the ends to the back pin the edges together in back to simulate the wrap this may help you decide what width and length you like if you are undecided on the length i recommend doing the seamed option you can add or subtract row before seaming to adjust the final length remember that different fabrics will drape differently a heavier or drapier fabric will fall longer down your arms than a light fluffy fabric even if they re the same width choose your yarn the pattern can be knit in any yarn and gauge you like but for best results use a yarn with good drape and which will not roll much when worked in stockinette such as linen or silk choose your stitch pattern the sample patterns are shown in stockinette but of course you can use any stitch pattern you like keep in mind that any
